content:
Interviewer: To start, I would like to begin with a big question: tell me the story of your life. Start from the beginning -- from your childhood, to education, to family and relationships, and to any major life events you may have had.

David Chen: I was born in Shanghai, China, but I moved to the United States when I was just five years old with my parents, who were both working in the textile industry. Life was tough at first—my family lived in a small apartment in a working-class neighborhood, and money was always tight. My parents didn't have much formal education, but they always emphasized the importance of learning. I remember staying up late with my mother, who would read me stories in Chinese even though she didn't have much schooling herself. I grew up speaking both Chinese and English, which I think helped me adapt to life here, though it wasn't always easy. I went to public school in Seattle, and while I was a good student, I didn't have access to the same resources as kids from wealthier families. I worked part-time at a local grocery store during high school to help support my family, which taught me a lot about responsibility and perseverance. I eventually earned a scholarship to a state university, where I studied economics, and later went on to get my master's degree. After college, I found a job in financial planning, which has been stable but not overly lucrative. I met my wife, Sarah, while we were both working at the same company, and we got married a few years ago. We have a young daughter, and while we're not wealthy, we're trying to build a better life for her—one where she has more opportunities than I did.

Interviewer: Some people tell us that they've reached a crossroads at some points in their life where multiple paths were available, and their choice then made a significant difference in defining who they are. What about you? Was there a moment like that for you, and if so, could you tell me the whole story about that from start to finish?

David Chen: Yes, there was one moment that really shaped the direction of my life. It happened when I was 17, right after my first year of college. I was working part-time at the grocery store, and I was also taking on extra shifts at a local community center where I volunteered to tutor kids from low-income families. One evening, after a particularly tough day, I sat down with one of the kids, a boy named Leo, who was about 12 years old. He was struggling with math, and I could see the frustration in his eyes. I remember telling him, 'You know, I didn't have much either when I was your age, but I kept pushing forward.' That conversation stayed with me. A few weeks later, Leo came up to me and said, 'You believe in me, and I want to believe in myself.' That moment made me realize the power of mentorship and the impact one person can have on another. It was then that I decided to pursue a career in financial planning—not just for the money, but to help others make better decisions for their futures. I enrolled in a graduate program with a focus on community economics, and that path led me to the job I have today. That crossroads wasn't just about choosing a career; it was about choosing to give back, and that decision has defined who I am ever since.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they made a conscious choice or decision in moments like these, while others say it 'just happened'. What about you?

David Chen: I think it was a conscious choice, but not one I made all at once. It was more like a series of small decisions that built on each other. When I was working at the grocery store and tutoring Leo, I realized that I didn't just want to survive—I wanted to help others avoid the struggles I had faced. That moment with Leo was the spark, but it took time to fully understand what I wanted to do with my life. I remember sitting with my parents one night after that conversation, telling them about my thoughts. My father, who never had much education, looked at me and said, 'If you're going to do something, do it right.' That stuck with me. I didn't just choose to go into financial planning; I chose to do it with a purpose—to make sure that people, especially those from backgrounds like mine, had the tools to build a better future. It wasn't just about me anymore; it was about the people I wanted to help. That choice didn't come easily, but it was the right one.

Interviewer: Do you think another person or an organization could have lent a helping hand during moments like this?

David Chen: Absolutely. In fact, I think without the support of a few key people and organizations, I might not be where I am today. When I was in high school, there was a teacher named Mrs. Ramirez who saw potential in me that I didn't always see in myself. She encouraged me to apply for scholarships and even helped me write my personal statement. Without her belief in me, I might not have gotten into college. Then, once I was in college, I was lucky to be part of a mentorship program through the university's financial aid office. My mentor, a financial advisor named James, took me under his wing and showed me what the field was really like. He didn't just teach me the technical skills; he taught me the importance of empathy and integrity in the work we do. I think people often underestimate how much a single mentor or a supportive program can change someone's trajectory. For someone like me, coming from a background where resources were limited, that kind of support was invaluable. It reminded me that while I had to fight for my opportunities, I wasn't alone in that fight.

Interviewer: Moving to present time, tell me more about family who are important to you. Do you have a partner, or children?

David Chen: Yes, I have a partner and a young daughter. My wife, Sarah, is a nurse at a local hospital, and she's been my rock through every step of this journey. We met while working at the same company, actually—she was in the administrative department, and I was handling some financial planning for the staff. We connected over our shared experiences of growing up in different environments; she was born in Texas but grew up in a small town in Oklahoma. She's always been passionate about helping others, which is one of the reasons I fell for her. We got married about five years ago, and last year we had our daughter, Emily. She's a bright, curious child, and I see so much of myself in her—especially that stubborn determination to keep pushing forward, no matter what. I want to make sure she has the opportunities I didn't, and I'm trying to be the kind of father that my parents couldn't always be because of their own struggles. It's a responsibility I take very seriously, and I hope I'm giving her a foundation that will allow her to dream bigger than I ever could.

Going through the interview questions made me reflect on how far I've come and how much the people and moments along the way have shaped who I am today. Starting with the story of my life, I realized how much resilience and support it took to get where I am. The crossroads I described with Leo was a turning point that made me realize I wanted to use my experiences to help others, not just for myself. It wasn't an instant decision, but a series of small choices that built into something bigger. I also thought about how much others have helped me along the way—teachers, mentors, and even my parents, who didn't have much but always believed in the value of education. And now, thinking about my family, especially my daughter Emily, I see the cycle continuing. I want to give her the opportunities I didn't have, and I hope I'm showing her the same determination and belief in herself that my parents and others instilled in me. This interview made me appreciate the journey more than ever.

Interviewer: Are there anyone else in your immediate family whom you have not mentioned? Who are they, and what is your relationship with them like?

David Chen: My immediate family includes my parents, who still live in Seattle, and my younger sister, Lin. My parents have always been a source of strength for me, even though they didn't have much in the way of education or financial stability. They worked multiple jobs to support our family, and I always admired their resilience. My sister, Lin, is ten years younger than me, and she's actually the one who inspired me to pursue higher education. She was the first in our family to graduate from college—she studied nursing, just like my wife, Sarah. Even though we didn't grow up together in the same way, we've always had a close bond. She's the one who encouraged me to apply for graduate school, and I still remember the night she called me and said, 'You can do this, David. You have more than you think.' Our relationship is built on mutual respect and support, and I'm grateful for her belief in me. Even though we come from a background where opportunities were limited, I think we've both found ways to make something of ourselves, and that gives me hope for the future.

Interviewer: Tell me about anyone else in your life we haven’t discussed (like friends or romantic partners). Are there people outside of your family who are important to you?

David Chen: Outside of my family, there are a few friends and colleagues who have been important to me along the way. One of them is Marcus, a friend from college who became a close confidant. We met in our economics class, and even though we had different backgrounds—Marcus was from a more affluent family—he always had a way of seeing the world that challenged me to think differently. He's now a policy analyst, and we often talk about how to make systemic changes that help people like us who come from less privileged backgrounds. He's been a sounding board for my ideas, and I've learned a lot from his perspective. Then there's James, my former mentor from the university, who I mentioned earlier. Even though he's retired now, he still keeps in touch and offers advice whenever I need it. I also have a few coworkers at my job who I consider friends—people who understand the challenges of balancing work, family, and personal growth. They've been there for me during tough times, and I feel lucky to have that support system. In the end, it's not just about family or career; it's about the people who believe in you, even when you don't believe in yourself.

Interviewer: Now let’s talk about your current neighborhood. Tell me all about the neighborhood and area in which you are living now.

David Chen: I live in a neighborhood in Seattle called Maplewood, which is a bit of a mix—there are older homes, some newer developments, and a lot of community spirit. It's not the most affluent area, but it's safe and has a strong sense of community. There's a local park where I take Emily to play, and it's become a gathering spot for families in the area. I like that we're close to public transportation, which makes it easier for me to commute to work, and there are a few community centers and libraries that I use regularly. One of the things I appreciate most about this neighborhood is the diversity—there are people from all walks of life, and it reminds me of the kind of place I want Emily to grow up in. I also volunteer at a community food bank nearby, which is something I feel strongly about. It's not perfect, but it's a place where I can contribute and feel connected to the people around me.

Interviewer: Some people say they feel really safe in their neighborhoods, others not so much. How about for you?

David Chen: I feel pretty safe here, honestly. There's a sense of community that makes a big difference. I know most of my neighbors by name, and there's always someone around if you need help. That said, I'm not naive—I know there are challenges in any city, especially with things like homelessness and crime. But compared to where I grew up, this feels like a safe and stable place to raise a child. I remember how scared I was as a kid, living in a place where you never knew what the next day would bring. Now, I can walk Emily to the park without worrying about her safety, and that gives me peace of mind. Safety isn't just about not being harmed—it's about feeling secure in your environment, and I think that's something this neighborhood provides, even if it's not perfect.

Interviewer: Living any place has its ups and downs. Tell me about what it’s been like for you living here.

David Chen: Living here has had its ups and downs, just like anywhere else. On the positive side, the community feels like a second family. There are block parties in the summer, and neighbors often check in on each other. I've even started a small book club with a few other parents in the area, which has been a nice way to connect and share experiences. But there are challenges too. The cost of living here is high, and even though I have a stable job, it's not always easy to make ends meet. I work full-time, and Sarah works long shifts at the hospital, so balancing work and family life can be tough. There are days when I feel overwhelmed, especially when I see how much more money some of my coworkers earn, even though we all do similar work. But I try to focus on the positives—like knowing that Emily is growing up in a place where she can feel safe, learn from others, and have access to resources I never had. It's not perfect, but it's a start.

Going through the interview questions about my family and neighborhood made me reflect on how much my life has evolved. Talking about my wife Sarah and daughter Emily reminded me of the love and support that have been crucial in my journey. It also made me think about how I want to be a better father than my parents could be, giving Emily the opportunities I didn't have. When I described my neighborhood, Maplewood, I realized how much I value the sense of community and safety it provides, especially for raising a child. It's comforting to know that even though we're not wealthy, we're in a place where people look out for each other. The interview made me appreciate how my family, my neighborhood, and the people in my life have all played a role in shaping who I am today.

Interviewer: Right now, across a typical week, how do your days vary?

David Chen: A typical week for me is pretty structured, though it varies depending on work and family commitments. I usually start my day around 6:30 a.m., getting up before the kids to get a few hours of work done before Sarah and Emily are up. I work from home a few days a week, which helps with the balance, but other days I have to commute into the city for meetings or client appointments. On weekdays, after work, I pick up Emily from daycare and we have dinner together, then I try to spend some quality time with her—reading, playing, or just talking. Sarah usually comes home late, so I take on most of the bedtime routine. On weekends, we try to go out as a family—sometimes to the park, sometimes to a museum or a coffee shop. I also make time to volunteer at the community food bank on Saturdays, which is something I really value. It's not always easy, but I try to keep things consistent so Emily knows what to expect. There are definitely days when I feel stretched thin, but I remind myself that this is the life I chose—one that's not about luxury, but about love, stability, and giving my daughter the best chance I can.

Interviewer: At what kind of job or jobs do you work, and when do you work?

David Chen: I work as a financial planner at a small firm downtown, specializing in helping individuals and families from lower-income backgrounds navigate financial planning, budgeting, and long-term savings. I work full-time, typically from Monday to Friday, though I often have to stay late on some days to meet with clients or prepare reports. My hours can be a bit irregular, especially when I'm volunteering at the food bank on Saturdays or helping Sarah with Emily when she's working late shifts. I find the work rewarding because it allows me to use the knowledge I've gained to help others avoid the struggles I faced growing up. It's not always easy—there are days when I feel like I'm not making enough of a difference, but I remind myself that even small steps can lead to bigger changes over time. I also take on some part-time consulting work for non-profits focused on economic empowerment, which gives me a chance to work on projects that align with my values. It's a busy life, but it's one I'm proud of, and I hope it sets a good example for Emily as she grows up.

Interviewer: Do you have other routines or responsibilities that you did not already share?

David Chen: Outside of work and family, I also have a few personal routines that help me stay grounded. I've always been into running, so I try to get in a few miles most mornings before work. It's my time to clear my head and reflect on the day ahead. I also make it a point to cook most nights—Sarah and I both grew up in households where meals were simple but meaningful, and I want Emily to experience that too. There's something about cooking together that brings people closer, and I love seeing her try new things in the kitchen. On the weekends, when I'm not volunteering or spending time with family, I enjoy reading—mostly non-fiction, especially books on economics or social policy. It keeps me informed and reminds me of why I chose this path in the first place. I also try to set aside time each week to check in with old friends or mentors, just to stay connected. Life is busy, but these small routines help me stay focused on what matters most.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes to your daily routine.

David Chen: One recent change to my daily routine has been incorporating more mindfulness practices into my mornings. I used to just run and then jump straight into work, but I've started doing a short meditation session before my run. It helps me center myself and approach the day with more clarity. I read an article a few months ago about how mindfulness can reduce stress, and since I've been feeling the weight of balancing work, family, and volunteering more than usual, I thought it was worth trying. It's still a work in progress, but I've noticed that I'm more patient with Emily and more focused at work. I also started journaling a few nights a week, mostly to reflect on my thoughts and feelings about the challenges we're facing as a family. It's not something I used to do, but I think it's helping me process things in a healthier way. I hope it sets an example for Emily too—that it's okay to take time to care for yourself, even when life gets busy.

Interviewer: If you have children, tell me about a typical weekday during the school year for your children. What is their daily routine? And what are after school activities your children participate in?

David Chen: Emily is in first grade now, and her typical weekday during the school year starts early—usually around 7:30 a.m. She gets up, has a quick breakfast, and then I take her to school. She loves her teacher, Ms. Angela, who's very encouraging and creative. After school, she comes home around 3 p.m., and we have a snack before she starts her after-school activities. She's in a small group for reading and math enrichment at the community center, which is run by a local nonprofit. It's a great program—they focus on building confidence and critical thinking, and I've seen her progress so much. On Mondays and Wednesdays, she also has a music class where she learns to play the piano. I know it's not much, but I want her to experience the joy of learning something new. After her activities, we have dinner together, and then I try to read to her or help her with her homework. It's not always easy—there are days when she's tired or frustrated, but I love seeing her determination. I hope these little things help her grow into someone who feels capable and curious about the world.

Going through the interview questions about my family and neighborhood made me reflect on how much my life has evolved. Talking about my wife Sarah and daughter Emily reminded me of the love and support that have been crucial in my journey. It also made me think about how I want to be a better father than my parents could be, giving Emily the opportunities I didn't have. When I described my neighborhood, Maplewood, I realized how much I value the sense of community and safety it provides, especially for raising a child. It's comforting to know that even though we're not wealthy, we're in a place where people look out for each other. The interview made me appreciate how my family, my neighborhood, and the people in my life have all played a role in shaping who I am today.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to learn more about your health. First, tell me all about your health.

David Chen: In terms of my health, I'd say I've been pretty fortunate. I don't have any major chronic conditions, but I do have some lingering issues from my childhood, like asthma, which I managed to keep under control with medication and lifestyle changes. I also have mild hypertension, which I monitor regularly through check-ups with my doctor. I try to stay as healthy as I can, partly because I want to be around for Emily and Sarah, and partly because I know how much my parents sacrificed to give me a chance at a better life. I make sure to eat well, exercise regularly, and get enough sleep, even when life gets busy. I also try to be mindful of stress, which I know can take a toll on the body. I've started seeing a therapist once a month to help me process some of the emotional challenges that come with balancing work, family, and my own goals. It's not always easy, but I believe taking care of my health is just as important as taking care of my family and my work.

Interviewer: For you, what makes it easy or hard to stay healthy?

David Chen: What makes it easy to stay healthy is having a routine and the support of my family. Sarah and I both prioritize eating well and exercising, even if it's just a quick walk or a run in the morning. Emily has also started to get into it—she loves helping me pack healthy lunches, and she's even started asking for more fruits and vegetables. The hardest part, though, is finding the time to take care of myself when work and family responsibilities pile up. There are days when I feel like I'm constantly running from one thing to the next, and it's easy to skip a meal or forget to take my medication. But I've learned that small habits—like drinking more water, getting enough sleep, or even just taking a few deep breaths when I'm stressed—can make a big difference. I think the key is not being too hard on myself when I slip up. Health isn't about perfection; it's about showing up for yourself and your family, even on the tough days.

Interviewer: Tell me about anything big that has happened in the past two years related to your health: any medical diagnoses, flare-ups of chronic conditions, broken bones, pain – anything like that.

David Chen: In the past two years, I've had a few health challenges that reminded me just how important it is to take care of myself. About a year ago, I started experiencing some back pain that I initially ignored, thinking it was just from sitting too long at my desk. But it got worse over time, and I finally saw a doctor. Turns out, I had a minor disc issue in my lower back, likely from years of carrying heavy grocery bags when I was younger and from sitting for long hours at work. I had to start physical therapy, which was a bit of a struggle at first because it meant adjusting my routine and being more mindful of how I moved throughout the day. But it's been helpful—my pain has lessened, and I've learned some exercises to keep my back strong. Around the same time, I also had a mild flare-up of my asthma, probably triggered by the stress of balancing work and family life. It was a wake-up call. I realized that my health isn't just about avoiding illness—it's about being proactive and listening to my body. I've made some changes since then, like taking more breaks during the workday and making sure I don't push myself too hard. It's not always easy, but I'm learning that taking care of my health is one of the most important things I can do for my family, especially Emily.

Interviewer: Sometimes, health problems get in the way. They can even affect people’s ability to work or care for their children. How about you?

David Chen: Honestly, there were times when my health issues did make things more challenging. The back pain, in particular, made it harder to keep up with the long hours at work and the physical demands of volunteering. There were days when I had to cancel meetings or take it easy at the food bank because I was too sore. It also affected my ability to be fully present with Emily—there were moments when I was distracted by the pain or too tired to play with her the way I wanted to. But I realized that if I didn't take care of myself, I wouldn't be able to take care of my family the way they deserve. So I started making small but consistent changes—like taking short walks during the day to stretch, setting reminders to take my medication, and even asking Sarah to help me with some of the heavier lifting at home. It wasn't easy, but I learned that health isn't just about being strong; it's about being resilient and knowing when to ask for help. I think that's something I want Emily to understand too—that it's okay to take a step back sometimes, as long as you're moving forward in the end.

Interviewer: Now we’re going to talk a bit more about what life was like for you over the past year. Tell me all about how you have been feeling.

David Chen: Over the past year, I've felt a mix of emotions—some days I feel like I'm making progress, and other days I feel like I'm just barely keeping up. Life has been busy, but in a way that feels meaningful. I've been trying to be more present for Emily, and I think I've gotten better at that. I remember one evening when she came home from school and said, 'Dad, I want to be just like you when I grow up.' It hit me hard because I never imagined someone would want to be me, but I realized that she sees the work I do as something important. That made me feel proud, but also a little overwhelmed, because I know how much more I have to do to make sure she has a better life than I did. I've also been reflecting a lot on my own journey—how far I've come, but also how much I still have to learn. I've started setting smaller goals for myself, like reading more to Emily or volunteering more consistently, and I think those small steps are helping me feel more grounded. There's still a lot of uncertainty, especially with the cost of living and the challenges of raising a child in this economy, but I'm trying to focus on what I can control and be grateful for the little things.

Going through the interview questions about my recent changes in routine and health made me realize how much I've grown in understanding the importance of self-care. Before, I used to think that being strong meant pushing through everything without pause, but now I see that taking time to breathe, meditate, and reflect is just as important as working hard or caring for my family. The mindfulness practices I've started, like meditation and journaling, have helped me feel more centered and patient, especially with Emily. It's also made me more aware of how my health affects not just me, but the people I love. I used to ignore my back pain or stress-related flare-ups, thinking I could just power through, but now I know that taking care of my body and mind is a way of showing up for my family. I hope that by modeling these habits for Emily, she'll learn that it's okay to take a step back when needed and that health is a lifelong journey, not a one-time goal.

Interviewer: Some people say they struggle with depression, anxiety, or something else like that. How about for you?

David Chen: I think I've struggled with anxiety from time to time, especially during the busier periods when work, family, and volunteering all feel like they're pulling me in different directions. There were moments when I felt like I wasn't doing enough for Emily or Sarah, or that I wasn't making a real difference in the lives of the people I work with. I used to push those feelings down, thinking that showing weakness would make me less of a provider or a role model. But over the past year, I've started to realize that it's okay to feel overwhelmed, and that asking for help isn't a sign of failure—it's a sign of strength. I've started talking to Sarah more about how I'm feeling, and I've even opened up to my therapist about the pressure I put on myself to be perfect for Emily. It's not easy, but I'm learning that taking care of my mental health is just as important as taking care of my physical health. I want Emily to grow up knowing that it's okay to feel scared or unsure sometimes, and that it's never too late to ask for support.

Interviewer: How has it been for your family?

David Chen: For my family, it's been a mix of challenges and moments of deep connection. Sarah has been incredible—she's always been the one to remind me to slow down and breathe when I'm feeling overwhelmed. She's had her own struggles too, especially with the long hours at the hospital and the emotional toll of caring for patients during these tough times. But she's strong, and she's always been there for me and Emily. As for Emily, she's growing up so fast, and I can already see her developing her own sense of curiosity and determination. She's not just copying me; she's forming her own ideas and opinions. I remember one day when she asked me, 'Why do you work so hard, Dad?' I told her it was to give her a better life, but she looked at me and said, 'I want to make you proud, too.' That moment really hit me—it reminded me that it's not just about what I do for her, but also about what she does for me. We're all learning, growing, and supporting each other, and I think that's what makes our family strong.

Interviewer: Some people say that religion or spirituality is important in their lives, for others not so much. How about you?

David Chen: I think religion has played a role in my life, though not in the way I used to think it would. When I was younger, I didn't have a strong religious identity—I was raised in a household where faith wasn't really discussed, and I didn't feel connected to any particular tradition. But as I've grown older, I've come to see spirituality more as a personal journey than something tied to a specific religion. I still identify as Protestant, largely because of my parents' background, but I don't attend church regularly. Instead, I find my sense of purpose and connection through my family, my work, and the people I help. I think of my parents' sacrifices and the values they passed down as a kind of spiritual foundation for me. I also find meaning in the small moments—like watching Emily learn to read or seeing a client finally feel empowered by their financial decisions. I don't know if I'd call it religion, but I do believe in something bigger than myself, and that belief has helped me get through some of the hardest times in my life.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they use Facebook, Instagram, or other social media to stay connected with the wider world. How about for you? Tell me all about how you use these types of platforms.

David Chen: I don't use social media very often, to be honest. I find that it can be a bit overwhelming with all the noise and comparison, and I prefer to keep my focus on the people and things that matter most to me. That said, I do use Facebook occasionally to stay in touch with family back in China, especially my parents and my sister. They don't use it much themselves, but they've learned how to navigate it enough to see photos of Emily and read updates about our lives. I also follow a few pages related to financial literacy and community development because they align with my work and values. I think social media can be a useful tool if used mindfully, but I've found that for me, it's more important to be present in the real world—whether that's at the park with Emily, volunteering at the food bank, or just having a quiet evening at home with Sarah. I don't want to let the virtual world take up too much of my time or energy when there's so much to experience right here, right now.

Interviewer: Some people say they use Facebook or Twitter to get (emotional or financial) support during tough times. What about you?

David Chen: Honestly, I haven't relied much on social media for support during tough times. I think I've always leaned more on the people I know in real life—my family, my friends, and the community I'm part of. When I was going through some of the hardest moments in my life, like when I was trying to balance work, family, and my health, it was my wife Sarah who was my emotional anchor. She's the one who reminded me that I wasn't alone, even when I felt like I was carrying everything on my own. I also found support in my colleagues at work and in the people I help through my financial planning. There's something about face-to-face connections or even a phone call that feels more genuine than scrolling through a feed. That said, I can see how it might help others, especially those who don't have a strong support network. I just know that for me, it's the people I love and the work I do that give me the strength to keep going.

Going through the interview questions about my health and recent challenges made me reflect on how much I've grown in understanding the importance of taking care of myself. Before, I used to think that being strong meant pushing through everything without pause, but now I see that taking time to breathe, meditate, and reflect is just as important as working hard or caring for my family. The mindfulness practices I've started, like meditation and journaling, have helped me feel more centered and patient, especially with Emily. It's also made me more aware of how my health affects not just me, but the people I love. I used to ignore my back pain or stress-related flare-ups, thinking I could just power through, but now I know that taking care of my body and mind is a way of showing up for my family. I hope that by modeling these habits for Emily, she'll learn that it's okay to take a step back when needed and that health is a lifelong journey, not a one-time goal.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes in your level of stress, worry, and your emotional coping strategies.

David Chen: In the past year, I've noticed my stress levels have fluctuated, especially with the demands of work, family, and my health. There were times when I felt like I was constantly juggling too many things at once, and I wasn't sure how to prioritize. But I've been working on developing better coping strategies. One of the biggest changes has been incorporating mindfulness into my daily routine, like the meditation and journaling I mentioned earlier. It's helped me process my emotions in a healthier way, rather than bottling them up. I've also started setting clearer boundaries between work and personal time—something I used to neglect because I thought I had to be available all the time. Another thing that's helped is talking more openly with Sarah about my feelings. She's been a great listener, and just being able to share my thoughts with her has made a world of difference. I've also found that spending time with Emily, even in small moments, helps me feel more grounded. Whether it's reading a story to her or just sitting quietly while she plays, those moments remind me of what truly matters. I'm not perfect at it, but I'm learning that taking time to reflect, connect, and breathe is just as important as pushing forward.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to talk about how you make ends meet and what the monthly budget looks like for you and your family. What were your biggest expenses last month?

David Chen: Last month, our biggest expenses were rent, groceries, and Emily's childcare and school supplies. Rent is the largest chunk of our budget—our apartment in Maplewood isn't cheap, especially with the cost of living in Seattle. We pay about $1,800 a month for it, and it's a tight fit for the three of us, but it's manageable. Groceries are another big one, especially since Sarah and I both work long hours and don't always have the time to cook from scratch. We try to buy in bulk and stick to seasonal produce to save where we can, but it still adds up. Emily's daycare is around $1,200 a month, and then there's the cost of her school supplies, extracurricular activities, and the occasional outing. We also have to budget for my car payments, insurance, and the medication I need for my back and asthma. It's a constant balancing act, and sometimes I feel like we're just one unexpected expense away from being stretched too thin. But we've learned to prioritize—things like eating out or buying new clothes are things we do less of, and we've gotten really creative with meals and activities to keep things affordable. I know it's not easy, but I'm proud of how we've managed to make it work, and I hope it sets a good example for Emily about being responsible and resourceful.

Interviewer: How much did your household spend in the past month? Is that the usual amount? And if not, how much do you usually spend and on what?

David Chen: Last month, our total household spending was around $4,200, which is pretty close to what we usually spend each month. The majority of that goes toward rent, childcare, and groceries, as I mentioned earlier. We also have regular expenses like utilities, internet, and car payments. On average, we spend about $1,800 on rent, $1,200 on daycare, and around $800 on groceries. Then there's about $500 for utilities and insurance, and another $400 for transportation and miscellaneous expenses like school supplies and activities for Emily. We don't have a lot of discretionary spending, but we do try to set aside a small amount each month for savings, even if it's just $100 or so. It's not much, but it's something. I know it's not the most comfortable life, but I feel like we're doing okay, and I'm trying to teach Emily that with careful planning and a little creativity, you can make the most of what you have.

Interviewer: Does your household own or rent your home?

David Chen: We rent our home. It's a two-bedroom apartment in Maplewood, and while it's not the most spacious, it's functional and comfortable for our family. Renting was the practical choice for us, especially with the way the housing market is here in Seattle. Buying a home feels out of reach right now, not just because of the high prices, but also because of the uncertainty in our financial situation. I know we're not alone in this—many people in our neighborhood are in similar situations, renting because it's more flexible, especially with the possibility of job changes or unexpected expenses. I've always believed that stability comes in many forms, and for now, renting gives us the flexibility we need to focus on what really matters—Emily's future, our health, and building a life that's rooted in community and purpose.

Interviewer: Bills can fluctuate over the course of a year. Seasons change, there are holidays and special events, school starts and ends, and so on. Tell me all about how your bills have fluctuated over the past year.

David Chen: Over the past year, our bills have definitely fluctuated, especially with the seasons and holidays. For example, during the winter months, our heating bill went up significantly because the apartment isn't very well insulated, and we had to use the space heater more often. That added about $100 to $150 to our monthly utility costs compared to the summer months. Then there's the holiday season—December was especially tough because we had to budget for gifts for Emily, a special dinner for our family, and even a small Christmas tree. We managed to keep it under control by being creative, like making some of the gifts ourselves or opting for experiences instead of physical items. Another big fluctuation was when Emily started first grade—there were unexpected costs for school supplies, uniforms, and even a few field trips. We also had to factor in the cost of her music lessons and the after-school enrichment program, which added a few hundred dollars a month. On the flip side, during the summer, we didn't have the daycare costs, which gave us a bit more breathing room. But even then, we had to plan for summer activities and maybe a vacation, which we managed to do by saving up a little each month. It's been a learning process, but I've come to appreciate how flexible we have to be with our budget, and I hope that teaches Emily the value of planning and adaptability.

Going through the interview questions from 26 to 30 made me reflect on how much my family and I have grown together, especially in the face of challenges. Talking about my mental health and how I've learned to ask for support reminded me of how important it is to be open with Sarah and to model that for Emily. It also made me realize how much I've come to value the real, in-person connections we have over virtual ones. I used to think that being strong meant hiding my struggles, but now I see that vulnerability is a form of strength, especially when it helps my family feel supported. I'm grateful for the people in my life who have been there for me, and I hope that by being honest about my emotions, I'm showing Emily that it's okay to feel overwhelmed and that asking for help is a sign of courage, not weakness.

Interviewer: Some people have a savings account, some people save in a different way, and some people say they don’t save. How about you?

David Chen: I try to save as much as I can, even if it's just a small amount each month. Right now, we have a savings account that we contribute to regularly—about $100 to $150 a month, depending on how our budget looks. It's not a lot, but it's something. I remember when I was growing up, my parents never had much savings, and that taught me the value of even the smallest amount set aside for the future. We also have an emergency fund, though it's not as large as we'd like it to be. It's been built up slowly over the years, mostly through cutting back on non-essential expenses and being mindful of our spending. I think the most important thing is that we're consistent about it. I want Emily to see that saving isn't about having a lot—it's about being responsible with what you have, and knowing that even small steps can add up over time. I also try to teach her about the importance of saving by involving her in our budget discussions, like letting her pick out a small item from our savings each month for something she wants. It's a way to make it real for her and help her understand that saving is a habit, not just a one-time thing.

Interviewer: Some people save for big things, like a home, while others save for a rainy day. How about for you (in the last year)?

David Chen: For me, saving has been more about building a rainy day fund than a specific big purchase like a home. I know that buying a house feels out of reach right now, especially with the high prices and the uncertainty of our financial situation. Instead, I've focused on creating a safety net so that if something unexpected happens—like a medical bill, a car repair, or even a period of unemployment—we won't be completely unprepared. Over the past year, we've been able to grow that emergency fund a little bit, though it's still not where we want it to be. I also try to save for smaller, meaningful things—like a family trip or a special experience for Emily. I remember when I was a kid, my parents never had much, and that taught me that saving isn't about having everything, but about being prepared for what life might throw your way. I want Emily to understand that too—that even small, consistent savings can make a big difference in the long run.

Interviewer: What is or was your occupation? In this occupation, what kind of work do you do and what are the most important activities or duties?

David Chen: My occupation is as a financial planner, and I specialize in helping individuals and families from lower-income backgrounds navigate financial planning, budgeting, and long-term savings. The most important activities in my work involve sitting down with clients one-on-one to understand their unique financial situations, goals, and challenges. I help them create realistic budgets, set up emergency funds, and explore ways to save for the future—whether that's for a child's education, a home, or simply financial stability. I also spend a lot of time educating them on financial literacy, because I know how much that can empower someone to make better decisions. One of the most rewarding parts of my job is seeing clients gain confidence in their ability to manage their money. It reminds me of my own journey, and it gives me a sense of purpose. I don't just see numbers and spreadsheets—I see people, and I want to help them build a better life, just like I hope to for Emily.

Interviewer: How many hours each week did you usually work?

David Chen: I usually work around 45 to 50 hours a week, though the hours can vary depending on the time of year and how many clients I have on my schedule. Some weeks are more intense, especially when I'm preparing for meetings or helping clients with more complex financial planning needs. I also take on some part-time consulting work for non-profits, which can add a few extra hours here and there. It's not always easy balancing work with everything else—like family, health, and volunteering—but I've learned to be efficient with my time. I try to be present for Emily as much as I can, even if it means working late some nights or coming in early on others. I know it's not perfect, but I believe in the work I do, and I hope that shows her that dedication and responsibility are important values to hold onto.

Interviewer: Did you have more than one job or business, including part time, evening, or weekend work?

David Chen: Yes, I actually did have more than one job at different points in my life, especially when I was younger and trying to support my family. In high school, I worked part-time at the grocery store, which was my first real job. It wasn't glamorous, but it taught me a lot about responsibility and the value of hard work. Later, while I was in college, I took on a second job as a tutor at the community center, which was how I met Leo. That experience was incredibly formative for me—it solidified my belief in the power of education and mentorship. After college, I worked full-time as a financial planner, but I also started taking on some part-time consulting work for non-profits focused on economic empowerment. It wasn't always easy juggling everything, but I found that having multiple streams of income helped me stay financially stable and gave me more flexibility in my career. I think those early experiences working multiple jobs taught me how to manage time and priorities, and they've stayed with me throughout my life. Even now, I still take on some part-time work outside of my main job, not just for the income, but because I want to stay connected to the community and continue giving back in whatever way I can.

Going through the interview questions from 31 to 35 made me reflect on how much I've grown in understanding the importance of managing stress, emotional well-being, and financial stability. Talking about my stress levels and coping strategies reminded me of how much I've learned to prioritize mindfulness, open communication with Sarah, and spending quality time with Emily. It also made me realize how much my mental health affects not just me, but the people I love. I used to think that being strong meant pushing through everything without pause, but now I see that taking time to breathe, meditate, and reflect is just as important as working hard or caring for my family. The recent challenges with my back pain, anxiety, and the fluctuating expenses have all shaped how I approach life now. I'm learning that it's okay to feel overwhelmed, and that asking for help isn't a sign of failure—it's a sign of strength. I hope that by modeling these habits for Emily, she'll learn that it's okay to take a step back when needed and that health, both mental and financial, is a lifelong journey, not a one-time goal.

Interviewer: In total, how much did your household make in the past month?

David Chen: In total, our household made around $5,200 in the past month. That comes from my full-time job as a financial planner and Sarah's nursing salary. It's not a huge amount, but it's enough to cover our basic needs and a little extra for savings and small indulgences. I know it's not easy, especially with the high cost of living here in Seattle, but we've learned to be resourceful. We don't have a lot of discretionary income, but we do what we can to make the most of what we have. I'm proud of how we've managed to keep our heads above water, and I hope that one day, Emily will look back on this time and see that her parents worked hard to give her a stable foundation, even if it wasn't perfect.

Interviewer: Tell me more about your workplace. How long have you been at your current job? How would you describe the benefits that come with your job? (This could include things like health benefits, paid time off, vacation, and sick time.)

David Chen: I've been at my current job for about six years now, and it's been a journey of growth and purpose. The benefits of the job are pretty standard—health insurance, which covers me and Sarah, and some dental and vision coverage. We also get paid time off, which is something I used to take for granted. In the past, when I was working multiple jobs, I didn't have the luxury of sick days or vacation time, so now I really appreciate being able to take a break when I need to, whether it's for a family event, a personal day, or just to recharge. The company also offers some professional development opportunities, like workshops on financial planning and community outreach, which I find really valuable. It's not a huge company, but it's supportive, and the people I work with are passionate about what they do. I think that's what makes the job meaningful for me—not just the paycheck, but the fact that I'm part of something that helps people build better lives, just like I hope to for Emily.

Interviewer: How would you describe your relationships at work? (How is your relationship with your manager or boss? How are your relationships with your coworkers?)

David Chen: My relationships at work are pretty positive overall. I've been lucky to have a manager, Karen, who's both supportive and understanding. She's been with the company for a while and has a real passion for what we do. She doesn't just focus on the numbers—she genuinely cares about her team and the impact we have on people's lives. I think that's why I've stayed at this job for so long. She's given me the freedom to be creative in how I approach my clients, and she's always been there to offer guidance when I needed it. As for my coworkers, we have a good rapport. We're all in this together, and even though we're busy, we make time to check in on each other. I remember one time when I was struggling with my back pain and had to take a few days off, and one of my coworkers, Lisa, actually stepped in and covered some of my meetings for me. That kind of support makes a big difference. I think the best part about my workplace is that it feels like a community, not just a job. We're all here because we want to help people, and that shared purpose makes the work feel meaningful, even on the tough days.

Interviewer: Tell me about how predictable your work schedule is. How would you describe your job in terms of flexibility with your hours?

David Chen: My work schedule is pretty predictable, but it does have some flexibility depending on the needs of my clients and the workload. I usually start my day around 8:30 a.m., though I often come in earlier if I need to get some work done before my family wakes up. My core hours are from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m., but I sometimes stay late to meet with clients or prepare reports, especially if I have a busy week. On the other hand, I also have the option to work from home a few days a week, which helps me balance my responsibilities better. The flexibility is something I really appreciate, especially as a father. It allows me to be there for Emily when I need to be, whether it's for a school event or just a quiet evening at home. That said, there are times when the schedule can feel rigid, especially when I have a lot of meetings back-to-back or when I'm juggling multiple projects. But overall, I think the predictability gives me a sense of stability, which is important for both my work and my family life.

Interviewer: Overall, how do you feel about your financial situation?

David Chen: Overall, I feel like we're managing, but it's not without its challenges. I know we're not wealthy, and there are days when I worry about whether we're doing enough for Emily or if we're setting her up for a better life than I had. But at the same time, I feel a sense of pride in how we've built a stable, loving home for her, even with the limitations. I've come to realize that financial security isn't just about having a lot of money—it's about having the freedom to make choices, to provide opportunities, and to feel secure in the future. I know we're not there yet, but I'm working toward it, and I hope that Emily grows up understanding that it's not about how much you have, but how you use what you have to make a difference in your own life and the lives of others.

Going through the interview questions from 36 to 40 made me reflect on how much my family and I have grown in understanding the importance of managing our finances and adapting to the fluctuations that come with life. Talking about our bills and how they change with the seasons, holidays, and school schedules reminded me of how much flexibility and planning are needed to keep things stable. It also made me think about how I want to teach Emily the value of budgeting, saving, and being responsible with money, even when we don't have a lot. I've learned that financial stability isn't about having everything, but about making the most of what you have and being prepared for what life might throw your way. It's not always easy, but I'm proud of how we've managed to keep our heads above water, and I hope that one day, Emily will look back on this time and see that her parents worked hard to give her a stable foundation, even if it wasn't perfect.

Interviewer: Did your mom/dad work for pay for at least a year while you were growing up?

David Chen: Yes, both my parents worked for pay while I was growing up, though it wasn't always easy for them. My father worked multiple jobs—mostly in manufacturing and construction—while my mother worked part-time at a local store, often cleaning or restocking shelves. They never had much in the way of benefits or job security, but they always made sure that I had what I needed for school and basic necessities. I remember watching my father come home exhausted after long shifts, and my mother would stay up late to make sure I had homework done and a meal on the table. They didn't have much education, but they taught me the value of hard work and resilience. I think that's why I always felt a responsibility to do well in school and make something of myself. Looking back, I realize how much sacrifice they made, and it's one of the reasons I'm so determined to give Emily the opportunities I didn't have. I want her to know that no matter where you come from, you can build a better life through perseverance and support from the people who believe in you.

Interviewer: What was their job? What kind of work did they do? What were their most important activities or duties?

David Chen: My father worked in manufacturing and construction, often taking on whatever job was available to make ends meet. He didn't have much formal training, but he was a hard worker and had a strong sense of responsibility. His most important duties were providing for our family, which meant working long hours, sometimes even two jobs at once. I remember him coming home exhausted, but he always made time to help me with my homework or talk to me about my day. My mother worked part-time at a local store, mostly doing cleaning and restocking shelves. Her work was less visible, but just as important—she made sure we had food on the table and that I had what I needed for school. Both of them taught me that work wasn't just about earning money; it was about contributing, about doing your best even when things were hard. I think that's why I value my job so much now—not just because it pays the bills, but because it gives me a sense of purpose, just like their work did for them.

Interviewer: What kind of place did they work for? What kind of business was them? What did they make or do?

David Chen: My father worked for small manufacturing plants and construction companies in Shanghai before we moved to the U.S. He didn't have much in the way of job security, but he always found work wherever he could. He was a manual laborer—lifting, welding, and assembling parts for machines. It was hard, physically demanding work, and he often came home with bruises or sore muscles. My mother worked at a local grocery store, which was owned by a family friend. She didn't have much in the way of formal training, but she was reliable and hardworking. She would clean the aisles, restock shelves, and sometimes help with customer service. She made sure we had food on the table and that I had what I needed for school, even if it meant sacrificing her own comfort. Looking back, I realize how much they gave up for me, and it's one of the reasons I'm so determined to give Emily the opportunities I didn't have. I want her to know that no matter where you come from, you can build a better life through perseverance and support from the people who believe in you.

Interviewer: We all have hopes about what our future will look like. Imagine yourself a few years from now. Maybe you want your life to be the same in some ways as it is now. Maybe you want it to be different in some ways. What do you hope for?

David Chen: A few years from now, I hope I'm still doing the work I love—helping people build better financial futures, especially those from backgrounds similar to mine. I hope Emily is growing into a confident, curious, and compassionate person, someone who knows she can achieve anything if she puts her mind to it. I hope she doesn't have to face the same struggles I did, but even if she does, I hope she has the resilience and support to keep going. I also hope that Sarah and I have managed to build a stronger financial foundation, maybe even have a small emergency fund that gives us more peace of mind. I don't know exactly what the future holds, but I hope it's filled with moments of connection, growth, and the kind of stability that allows us to be present for each other. Most of all, I hope I'm still learning, still growing, and still finding ways to give back to the community that helped me along the way.

Interviewer: What do you value the most in your life?

David Chen: What I value the most in my life is the people I love—the ones who have supported me through every step of my journey. My parents, despite their limited means, gave me the foundation of hard work and resilience. My wife Sarah, with her unwavering strength and compassion, has been my partner not just in life, but in every challenge we've faced. And my daughter Emily—she's the reason I push harder every day, the reason I want to build a better future. I also value the sense of purpose that comes from helping others, especially those who come from backgrounds like mine. There's something deeply meaningful about knowing that the struggles I've faced haven't been in vain, that I can use my experiences to make a difference in someone else's life. And finally, I value the small, everyday moments—the laughter with Emily, the quiet evenings with Sarah, the sense of community in Maplewood. Life hasn't always been easy, but these things have given me the strength to keep going.

Going through the interview questions from 41 to 45 made me reflect on how much my work and relationships at my job have shaped my sense of purpose and stability. Discussing my workplace and the benefits I receive brought back memories of my parents' struggles, and how different it is to have health insurance, paid time off, and the chance to grow professionally. It also made me appreciate the supportive relationships I have with my manager and coworkers, who understand the challenges of balancing work and family life. I realized that while my job isn't perfect, it gives me the flexibility and purpose I need to be there for my family and continue helping others in the way my parents and mentors helped me. It's a reminder that even in difficult times, having a job that aligns with my values and supports my family is something to be thankful for.

Going through this complete interview and life story has been a deeply reflective experience for me. It's reminded me of how far I've come—from the struggles of my childhood in Shanghai, moving to a new country with little, to the moments of clarity and purpose that shaped my path. I see how the people in my life—my parents, my wife Sarah, my daughter Emily, my mentors, and the community in Maplewood—have all played a role in who I am today. This journey hasn't been easy, but it's been meaningful. I've learned that resilience isn't just about enduring hardship; it's about finding purpose in it and using it to help others. I've also come to understand the importance of self-care, emotional honesty, and the value of small, consistent efforts in building a better life. This interview has given me a chance to look back and appreciate the strength it took to get here, while also looking forward with hope for what's yet to come for my family and the people I serve.
